head.title: Rising Gas Prices Don't Merit Our Tears

hedline.hl1: Rising Gas Prices Don't Merit Our Tears

block.p: "At the Pumps, High-Octane Pain" (news article, May 3) is disappointing. In spite of your descriptions of a truck driver torn from his family and children forced "to ante up a little extra" by an ice-cream vendor feeling the pinch, I was unmoved.

"At the Pumps, High-Octane Pain" (news article, May 3) is disappointing. In spite of your descriptions of a truck driver torn from his family and children forced "to ante up a little extra" by an ice-cream vendor feeling the pinch, I was unmoved.
You frame the problem of gas prices as a power imbalance between corporations and consumers. You suggest that the American middle class has suffered from paying a little extra at the pump.

But even as some wasteful car owners grudgingly acknowledge, we cannot continue our present consumption. Like the trucker in your article, I know many drivers who talk about the shortage of fossil fuels and get in their cars to drive five blocks to the store. I would love to see the cost of gas rise to the European price of $4 a gallon. Maybe then talk won't be so cheap.
